Issues.Title: [Question] Is the documented limitations for Control correct or is it overly generalized?
Issues.Body:
This is about **the Docs**. This is a **question**. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** This is about the Bulma **Docs** I'm using Bulma **version** [0.7.4] My **browser** is: Google Chrome Version 78.0.3904.108 (Official Build) (64-bit) I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** ### Description The documentation for [form control ](https://bulma.io/documentation/form/general/#form-control)says: > The Bulma control is a versatile block container meant to enhance single form controls. Because it has the same height as the element that it wraps, it can only contain the following Bulma elements: > > * `input` > * `select` > * `button` > * `icon` However, in reading the blog post from 2017 where [control was split into field and control in v.04.0](https://bulma.io/2017/03/10/new-field-element/), the examples cover using a `span` inside a control and why I can't have a complex control of HTML elements inside a control element: ```html

This username is available

This username is available

``` ### Steps to Reproduce Not exactly steps to reproduce, but additional context: I'm asking specifically because I want to use Bulma with Telerik Kendo UI, and Kendo UI translates it's "`` element into something like the following for an empty dropdown list, and its top-level elements are span and input, which violates the rules in the Bulma documentation HOWEVER everything seems to "work ok" - I think this is because the span is actually the floating listbox and therefore not part of the actual layout rules applied by Bulma, but it's been about 3+ years since I last did Web apps: ```html

``` ### Expected behavior Clarify documentation that a control can contain the four elements, or any element that is not directly in the layout of the control element (e.g., floating above as in a pop-up control) ### Actual behavior It seems to be OK to have spans and other elements, as long as it's not directly in the element's "has layout" path. But, again, it's been 3+ years since I've built a Web app, so I may be overlooking something, especially with Flexbox, as this is my first Flexbox app.

Issues.Title: Part 3: What's with Jeremy Thomas closing important issues before we even get a chance to reply?
Issues.Body:
> It seems your ideas are not compatible with the very foundation of Bulma: CSS classes are independent from the underlying HTML. This separation method allows the semantics of the HTML to be freely chosen by the user.
>
> That's why people pick Bulma: they can simply add some base classes, a few modifiers, and their styling is done!
>
> You write the HTML you want. Bulma does the rest.

That's the point I'm trying to make -- that this is simply just idn't the case!

Bulma allows you to add a few cases, a few modifiers, and you're done -- that part is fine.

But, unfortunately, Bulma requires you to drastically alter your HTML, and even insert unnecessary tags where classes could be used instead. You talk about me not understanding semantic HTML, with all due respect I think it's the other way around.

I'm just asking you to make Bulma more consistent by sticking to your core principle of using clean, simple and self-explanatory classes without interfering with ones HTML up to the point where you have to use old style tags to get what you want, and in addition put tags inside tags inside tags inside tags like some sort of Russian doll.

Having said that, I wish you good luck as well, and may all of Bootstrap's users become your users one day. Cheers!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Part 3: What's with Jeremy Thomas closing important issues before we even get a chance to reply?" (#2725)

Issues.Title: [REQUEST] Making Bulma even cleaner and more structural
Issues.Body:
Bulma is supposed to be a cleaner, simpler alternative to Bootstrap. While that's certainly true, it still has some way to go. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_HTML. @jgthms argues that semantic HTML does not apply to class names. That is simply not the case, as Bulma's classes need to be inside the HTML. Good semantic HTML means it should have tags and classes that reflect the structure or meaning of its content, and not its looks. Although the nature of CSS frameworks require us to use classes that represents looks, it doesn't mean we can't use meaningful names or have clean structures. In the the far future, however, we might see CSS frameworks where classes being assigned to perfectly semantic HTML through some middle layer. But for now, let's clean up Bulma. - Bulma general requirement of tag inside tag inside tag is one example of it polluting the structure and meaning of the HTML. - Class names with unclear meaning such as `is-1`, `is-2` etc. These might need to work in tandem with other classes that provide more meaning, but alone they don't make any sense. Also, we should avoid using numbers where possible and use `small`, `medium`, `big` etc. - Another is the use of 90s style tags such as ``, ``, `
` etc. when these could be classes such as `has-strong-text`, `has-small-text`, `has-horizontal-ruler` etc. - Sometimes unclear where classes should be assigned. Directly on the element or through one of its parents? Depending on the situation, sometimes the former works and sometimes the latter. It should work on both. - There should be no need for unnecessary repetition of classes such as `navbar-item` when it should be obvious that items within the navbar are just that - items. In addition, in semantic HTML `
    ` and `
  • ` would be the more proper. Ie. why can't this: ```
    MyLogo <-- Bulma should know this is the logo since its parent's name is "navbar-brand"
    Link 1 <-- Same here, Bulma should know this is a navbar item Link 2
    ``` Be more like this: ```
    MyLogo
    • Link 1
    • Link 2
    ``` Hopefully Bulma, with all its funding and public backing, can make something like this happen in the near future. Thanks! --VVGG P.S. Someone please make a subreddit or something so we can discuss cases like these without having our issues closed and therefore hidden from public view.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[REQUEST] Making Bulma even cleaner and more structural" (#2719)

Issues.Body:
This is about Bulma CSS framework .

I can't scope Bulma's grid properly in scss environment.

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->

When I try to scope Bulma grid in scss environment like below,

```
.my-scope {
  @import "~bulma/sass/grid/_all"
}
```

I get compiled css like below (actual behavior)
```
.columns.is-mobile > .my-scope .column.is-narrow {
...
}
```

instead of (expected behavior)
```
.my-scope .columns.is-mobile > .column.is-narrow {
...
}
```

I assume it is because of ampersand as a parent selector used in `grid.scss` ([like this one](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/c2fae7154b7fdfb957cb053a52bcf26f928a35f7/sass/grid/columns.sass#L9)) 

**For more context:**

I initially was looking for a solution to namespace, then followed one of suggestion in this issue thread (https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/issues/302#issuecomment-426051255)  I am kind of surprised that nobody had the same issue to scope grid, so wondering if there is any workaround that I am missing. If there is any, I will appreciate it üôè  

Thanks for your hard work on Bulma!

Issues.Title: Colors are hard-set for h and strong tags
Issues.Body:
I have a question about Bulma version 0.8.0. I could not find a duplicate of this question.

Is there a reason why colors are so hard set in Bulma? For instance, a strong element by default has a dark grey color. Now whenever I use a strong element inside a .card with a .has-background-black the text within the strong text is hardly readable. Even when I add the  .has-text-white class to the card the strong text will remain dark grey. I can add the .has-text-white class to the strong element of course but this must be a work around and more importantly this won't work inside a WYSIWYG editor.

The same goes for h tags that also have their colors hard set.

Wouldn't it be better to remove these colors and make these elements take the color set as the default for the body or a some other parent?

Issues.Body:
I found it difficult to place content into the body of a full-height hero that used up all of the available vertical space in the body.  The goal was to stretch the divs to take up the complete hero body.  I found this article about how to do this with flexbox:
https://css-tricks.com/boxes-fill-height-dont-squish/

I created an example to illustrate.  The hero body has four divs.  The first and second divs do not have any modifiers, so they are sized normally to fit their content.  The third and fourth divs have a modifier class "is-max-height," which divides all of the remaining vertical space between them, increasing their height.  The fourth also has a modifier class "is-vertically-centered" which makes the content centered vertically in the div.
https://codepen.io/RobJacobson/pen/QWWJPWK

This seems like a common use-case.  Are there any existing modifiers in Bulma that allow this?  (I.e., am I reinventing the wheel?)  If not, I'd propose adding classes like these, along with supporting documentation/examples on the website.  I think this would  be quite useful.

Also, I'd like to suggest creating a layout control for full-page content that isn't a hero.  It seems to be a common practice to use a hero for full-page content, such as in the linked tutorial (which is excellent).  However, this seems to me like "overloading" the hero class when it's used as a general layout tool for full-page layouts.  It works, but it seems weird -- using a hero for something that doesn't have traditional "hero" content.
https://scrimba.com/p/pV5eHk/cvrwyfR
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Feature Request] Classes to fill available vertical space" (#2704)
